words.definition: not perturbed or disconcerted
words.verbalIllustration: the protestors were unfazed by the prospect of arrest

words.definition: a child who behaves very badly : an annoying child
words.verbalIllustration: a bunch of ill-mannered little brats

words.definition: feeling or displaying no fear by temperament
words.verbalIllustration: undaunted despite their repeated failures at starting a business

words.definition: annoyed or angry
words.verbalIllustration: I was cross with her for being so careless

words.definition: to cause someone to be worried or upset
words.verbalIllustration: It perturbed him that his son was thinking about leaving school

words.definition: to look through (as a place) carefully or thoroughly in an effort to find or discover something
words.verbalIllustration: the owner of the bed-and-breakfast often trolls antique stores for furniture and knickknacks

words.definition: :to proceed or move quickly
words.verbalIllustration: everyone scurried back to work as soon as they had finished their lunch in the cafeteria

words.definition: to move or act slowly
words.verbalIllustration: if you continue to dawdle, we'll be late for sure

words.definition: to make an irregular series of quick, sudden movements
words.verbalIllustration: the housefly darted about the room until it found an open window and flew out

words.definition: :to put up (a sign, notice, etc.) so that it can be seen by many people
words.verbalIllustration: The professor posted (up) the students's exam grades outside her office

words.definition: :to make (something) officially known to many people
words.verbalIllustration: The company posted increased profits for the third quarter.

words.definition: :to add (a message) to an online message board
words.verbalIllustration: She posts regularly to several newsgroups.

words.definition: :to assign (someone, such as a guard) to stand or stay at a particular place
words.verbalIllustration: Paramedics were posted nearby.

words.definition: :a piece of wood or metal that is set in an upright position into or on the ground especially as a support or marker
words.verbalIllustration: fence posts

words.definition: :to set (something) in a tightly closed position
words.verbalIllustration: His jaw clenched and unclenched as he listened to the speech.

words.definition: :to hold (something) tightly
words.verbalIllustration: She danced alone, with a rose clenched in her teeth.

words.definition: :the act or manner of holding
words.verbalIllustration: fearful that his suitcase might be stolen, he never once relaxed his clench on the handle

words.definition: :to have or keep in one's hands
words.verbalIllustration: clenched a tissue in his hands as he told his story of misfortune

words.definition: :to have or keep in one's hands
words.verbalIllustration: he clutched the eggs carefully so he wouldn't drop them

words.definition: :to fasten (something) with a clasp
words.verbalIllustration: He clasped the keys to his belt

words.definition: :to hold (someone or something) tightly with your hands or arms
words.verbalIllustration: He clasped her hand gently/firmly.

words.definition: :to cause (as a person) to become filled or saturated with a certain quality or principle
words.verbalIllustration: invested the film with his own enthusiasm for the wonders of flight

words.definition: :to furnish freely or naturally with some power, quality, or attribute
words.verbalIllustration: a woman invested with the strong desire to make the world a better place

words.definition: :a number of things considered as a unit
words.verbalIllustration: a clutch of medals adorned the general's chest

words.definition: :a usually small number of persons considered as a unit
words.verbalIllustration: a clutch of people traveling together

words.definition: :a time or state of affairs requiring prompt or decisive action
words.verbalIllustration: a football quarterback who always comes through in the clutch

words.definition: :the right or means to command or control others
words.verbalIllustration: a nation no longer living in the clutch of a cruel tyrant

words.definition: :to make (someone) feel annoyed or angry
words.verbalIllustration: It galls me that such a small group of people can have so much power.

words.definition: to remain in place in readiness or expectation of something
words.verbalIllustration: decided to bide her time until she had an opportunity to switch jobs

words.definition: :something that can be used for a particular purpose
words.verbalIllustration: Now that he's a writer, he regards his difficult childhood experience as grist for the mill.

words.definition: :to read or look at something quickly
words.verbalIllustration: Please run your eye over this and let me know what you think.

words.definition: :to quickly read or look at (something, such as a list)
words.verbalIllustration: She ran her eye down the list looking for her name.

words.definition: :deeply involved in or affected by something
words.verbalIllustration: We're up to our eyes in work. [=we are very busy]

words.definition: an act or period of watching for signs of activity, danger, or opportunity
words.verbalIllustration: kept vigil at their ailing son's bedside the entire time he was in the hospital

words.definition: :unable to decide about something
words.verbalIllustration: He tried to persuade those still (sitting) on the fence to vote in his favor.

words.definition: 1:to start to be comfortable in a new situation 2:to begin to be confident or successful
words.verbalIllustration: 1. They quickly found their feet in their adopted country. 2. I was away for a long time, so it will take me a while to find my feet again.
